content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Answer the following questions about potassium hydrogen tartrate, <math alttext="K H C 4 H 4 O 6" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>KHC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub></math>. When <math alttext="K H C 4 H 4 O 6" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>KHC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub></math> dissolves in water, it dissociates into <math alttext="K with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></math> and <math alttext="H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>-</mo></msup></math> ions. The Lewis diagram of <math alttext="H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>-</mo></msup></math>is shown. A. In the diagram, circle the atom that detaches when <math alttext="H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>-</mo></msup></math> acts as a proton donor.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Answer the following questions about potassium hydrogen tartrate, <math alttext="K H C 4 H 4 O 6" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>KHC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub></math>. When <math alttext="K H C 4 H 4 O 6" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>KHC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub></math> dissolves in water, it dissociates into <math alttext="K with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></math> and <math alttext="H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>-</mo></msup></math> ions. The Lewis diagram of <math alttext="H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>-</mo></msup></math>is shown. A. In the diagram, circle the atom that detaches when <math alttext="H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>-</mo></msup></math> acts as a proton donor.

The <math alttext="H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>-</mo></msup></math> ion can act as a proton donor and a proton acceptor. The ionization reactions of <math alttext="H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>−</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> in water and their corresponding <math alttext="K" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math> values are provided. <math alttext="Line 1: H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid is in equilibrium with C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 2 charge, aqueous, plus H 3 O with a positive 1 charge, aqueous; where K a equals 4.5 times 10 to the negative 5 power. Line 2: H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid is in equilibrium with H 2 C 4 H 4 O 6, aqueous, plus O H with a negative 1 charge, aqueous; where K b equals 9.5 times 10 to the negative 12 power." overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtable columnalign="left"><mtr><mtd><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>−</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><msup><mtext>O</mtext><mo>+</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>4.5</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>−</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mtext>OH</mtext><mo>−</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>b</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>9.5</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></msup></mtd></mtr></mtable></mstyle></math> B. Calculate the <math alttext="p K a" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>a</mi></msub></math> of <math alttext="H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>-</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>.

C. When <math alttext="H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>-</mo></msup></math> is dissolved in water, <math alttext="the molar concentration of C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>-</mo></mrow></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">]</mi></math> is greater than <math alttext="the molar concentration of H 2 C 4 H 4 O 6" overflow="scroll"><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mtext>]</mtext></math>. Explain this observation based on the information provided.

Unlike many potassium salts, <math alttext="K H C 4 H 4 O 6" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>KHC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub></math> is only slightly soluble in water. It dissociates according to the following equation. The <math alttext="K s p" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math> expression is given. <math alttext="K H C 4 H 4 O 6, solid is in equilibrium with K with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, plus H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge, aqueous; where K s p equals, the molar concentration of K with a positive 1 charge, times the molar concentration of H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge." overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>KHC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>-</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>-</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">]</mi></math> In order to determine the <math alttext="K s p" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math> of this salt, a student prepares a saturated solution as shown in diagram 1. Diagram 1 Approximately <math alttext="2.0 grams" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.0</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> of <math alttext="K H C 4 H 4 O 6" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>KHC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub></math> is mixed with <math alttext="150 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mn>150</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>mL</mi></math> of water in a beaker. The mixture is stirred overnight and then allowed to settle. The beaker is shown after the contents have settled. D. What observation can the student make to confirm that the solution in the beaker is saturated?

E. The student continues the experiment by filtering the saturated solution and then titrating it with <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mi>NaOH</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>. These steps are shown in diagrams 2 and 3. Diagram 2 Diagram 3 The mixture is filtered to separate the solid from the solution. A <math alttext="25.00 milliliter" overflow="scroll"><mn>25.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>mL</mi></math> sample of the solution is transferred to an Erlenmeyer flask and titrated with <math alttext="0.1376 molar N a O H, aqueous." overflow="scroll"><mn>0.1376</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>NaOH</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>.</mo></math> The magnified view in diagram 3 shows part of the buret at the equivalence point of the titration. The remaining data are shown in the following table. Volume of <math alttext="K H C 4 H 4 O 6" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>KHC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub></math> solution in the flask <math alttext="25.00 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mn>25.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></math> Initial buret reading of <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mi>NaOH</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> <math alttext="0.00 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></math> Final buret reading of <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mi>NaOH</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> <math alttext="question mark" overflow="scroll"><mo>?</mo></math> Concentration of <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mi>NaOH</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> in the buret <math alttext="0.1376 molar" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.1376</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></math> i. Based on the magnified view in diagram 3, what should the student record as the final volume reading of <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mi>NaOH</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> in the buret? _______________<math alttext="blank milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mi>mL</mi></math>

ii. Using the data from the titration, calculate the value of <math alttext="the molar concentration of H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>-</mo></msup><mtext>]</mtext></math> in the <math alttext="K H C 4 H 4 O 6" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>KHC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub></math> solution. The equation shown represents the reaction that occurs during the titration. <math alttext="H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge, aqueous, plus O H with a negative 1 charge, aqueous, reacts to produce C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 2 charge, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mpadded><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>-</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>OH</mi><mo lspace="0.05em" rspace="0.05em">-</mo></msup></mpadded><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>→</mo><mpadded><mpadded><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>-</mo></mrow></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mpadded><mo>+</mo></mpadded><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>l</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mpadded></math>

iii. Using the data from the experiment, calculate the value of <math alttext="K s p" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math> for <math alttext="K H C 4 H 4 O 6" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>KHC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub></math>, given that <math alttext="K s p equals, the molar concentration of K with a positive 1 charge, times the molar concentration of H C 4 H 4 O 6 with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mtext>K</mtext><mo>+</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mtext>HC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo>-</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></math>.

F. A second student performs the same experiment, but some <math alttext="K H C 4 H 4 O 6, solid" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>KHC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> passes around the filter paper and remains in the <math alttext="25.00 milliliter" overflow="scroll"><mn>25.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></math> sample that is titrated. As a result, the second student requires a greater volume of <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mi>NaOH</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> to reach the equivalence point of the titration. i. Assuming no other errors occurred, explain why the presence of the <math alttext="K H C 4 H 4 O 6, solid" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>KHC</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> increases the volume of <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mi>NaOH</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> needed to reach the equivalence point.

ii. Would the second student’s calculated value of <math alttext="K s p" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math> be larger, smaller, or the same as the first student’s calculated value of <math alttext="K s p" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math> obtained in part E (iii)? Justify your answer.

skill.text: 2.D: Make observations or collect data from representations of laboratory setups or results, while attending to precision where appropriate.
